Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant and \\( i \\) denotes the imaginary unit. This function is subjected to a Fourier transform, represented as \\( \hat{z}(\xi) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-i\xi t} z(t) dt \\).

If \\( z(t) \\) is directly subjected to the Fourier transform without any modifications, will the result \\( \hat{z}(\xi) \\) be a delta function centered at \\( \xi = \omega \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) is indeed a delta function \\( \delta(\xi - \omega) \\). This indicates that the transform acts as an identity over the frequency component \\( \omega \\), perfectly capturing the unique frequency present in \\( z(t) \\).
